  {
    "sha": "07d1c53fd8143aadaed8d45b5ca6304c91ca4783",
    "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/agent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 54,
    "deletions": 35,
    "changes": 89,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -6,87 +6,106 @@ author: shlipsey3\n manager: pmwongera\n \n ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n-ms.date: 08/12/2025\n+ms.date: 08/28/2025\n \n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: concept-article\n ms.custom: security-copilot\n ms.collection: msec-ai-copilot\n ---\n-# Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout (preview)\n+# Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout\n \n-The Conditional Access optimization agent for Microsoft Entra includes a preview phased rollout capability that helps organizations deploy new Conditional Access policies safely and efficiently. This Microsoft Security Copilot feature in Microsoft Entra enables administrators to introduce policies gradually, monitor their impact, and minimize disruptions. There are several benefits to this phased rollout capability:\n-\n-- **User impact mitigation**: Gradual deployment minimizes the chance of widespread disruption to end users.\n-- **Operational efficiency**: Reduces the need for manual analysis and planning, saving weeks of effort.\n-- **Customization**: Administrators retain full control over group selection and rollout pacing.\n-- **Transparency**: The agent provides clear reasoning for group assignments and rollout decisions.\n+The Conditional Access optimization agent for Microsoft Entra includes a phased rollout capability that helps organizations deploy new Conditional Access policies safely and efficiently. This Microsoft Security Copilot feature in Microsoft Entra enables administrators to introduce policies gradually, monitor their impact, and minimize disruptions. This phased rollout capability provides gradual deployment of new policies to minimize the chance of widespread disruption to end users and reduce the need for manual analysis and planning, saving weeks of effort. As with all aspects of the Conditional Access Optimization Agent, administrators retain full control of the policy changes, such as group selection and rollout pacing. Clear reasoning for the rollout plan is also provided to maintain transparency.\n \n This article explains how the phased rollout process works, outlines prerequisites, and describes the built-in safeguards that help ensure a smooth deployment.\n \n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> The phased rollout capability in the Conditional Access Optimization agent is currently in PREVIEW.\n-> This information relates to a prerelease product that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\n-\n ## Prerequisites\n \n - You must have at least the [Microsoft Entra ID P1](overview.md#license-requirements) license.\n - You must have available [security compute units (SCU)](/copilot/security/manage-usage).\n-- [Global Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) and [Security Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-reader) roles can view the agent and any suggestions, but can't take any actions.\n-- [Global Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator), [Security Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator), and [Conditional Access Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator) roles can view the agent and take action on the suggestions.\n+- [Security Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-reader) and [Global Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) roles can view the agent and any suggestions, but can't take any actions.\n+- [Conditional Access Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator), [Security Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator), and [Global Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator) roles can view the agent and take action on the suggestions.\n+- Tenants must have at least five defined groups that are currently used in Conditional Access policies for the agent to generate a phased rollout plan.\n \n ## How it works\n \n-When the Conditional Access optimization agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, it can suggest turning on the policy with a phased rollout. The agent analyzes sign-in data and existing policies to define a phased rollout plan. There are three main steps in the phased rollout process.\n+When the Conditional Access optimization agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, it can suggest turning on the policy with a phased rollout. The agent analyzes sign-in data and existing policies to define a phased rollout plan.\n+\n+Policies that are intended to apply to *all users* and need to be turned on are eligible for a phased rollout. Because there are five distinct phases to a rollout plan, you must have at least five groups for the rollout plan to apply. To determine which groups to use, the agent looks at groups that were previously or are currently used in Conditional Access policies. The agent looks at those groups to see how other Conditional Access policies affected them, to gauge potential impact. The agent looks at the size of the groups and then uses all these factors to assign the groups to the phases starting with the low impact groups and ending with the higher-impact groups.\n+\n+There are three steps in the phased rollout process:\n \n-### Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout\n+1. [Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout](#agent-creates-a-report-only-policy-with-a-phased-rollout)\n+1. [Administrator reviews, edits, and accepts the rollout plan](#administrator-reviews-edits-and-accepts-the-rollout-plan)\n+1. [Agent or Administrator executes the approved rollout plan](#agent-or-administrator-executes-the-approved-rollout-plan)\n+\n+You can review the groups included in each phase and the number of days between each phase and make changes before and during the phased rollout. At any time during the rollout, you can choose to have the plan executed by the agent or you can manually execute each phase of the plan.\n+\n+Regardless of how the plan is executed or if you made changes to the plan, when the first phase starts, a *new* policy is created and turned on for the groups included in the first phase. The original report-only mode policy remains intact.\n+\n+## Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout\n \n The agent creates a report-only policy and builds a separate phased rollout plan. The rollout plans include five phases, starting with small, low-risk groups and progressing to larger, high-risk groups.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-policy-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout policy suggestion.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-policy-details.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the agent suggestions with a phased rollout type highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions-expanded.png\":::\n \n-### Administrator reviews and accepts the rollout plan\n+In the list of suggestions from the agent, look for **Suggested phased rollout** in the **Actions taken by agent** column.\n \n-Administrators review the details of the plan and can accept it or modify the group assignments or the time between phases.\n+### Administrator reviews, edits, and accepts the rollout plan\n \n-To adjust the groups included in a phase:\n+Administrators need to review the details of the plan, including the groups included in each phase, the timing of each phase, and how the plan will be executed.\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Security Administrator](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator).\n \n 1. Browse to **Conditional Access Optimization Agent** and select the **Review suggestions** button for a policy suggestion that includes a phased rollout.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the agent suggestions with a phased rollout type highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions-expanded.png\":::\n-\n 1. From the policy details page, select **Review phases**.\n \n-1. Select the pencil icon to edit the groups included in the phase.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout policy suggestion.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases-button.png\":::\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phases that can be edited.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases.png\":::\n+1. Select **Edit Groups** to edit the groups included in the phase.\n \n-1. Edit the groups by either adding or removing them from the phase. Select the **Select** button to save the changes.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-edit-groups-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phases that can be edited with the edit groups button highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-edit-groups-button.png\":::\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-group-edit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phase group edit options.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-group-edit.png\":::\n+1. Select the down arrow on the **Automatically roll out phases** button to select an execution mode.\n+    - **Automatically roll out phases**: Agent automatically rolls out each phase, based on timing and impact signals.\n+    - **Manually roll out phases**: Administrator manually advances each phase of the rollout.\n \n-1. Select **Apply suggestion** to save the changes to the groups and accept the rollout plan.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-execution-mode-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the option to change execution mode.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-execution-mode-button.png\":::\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> You can intervene at any time with automatic and manual rollout plans. You can also change execution modes at any time during rollout.\n \n To adjust the time between phases:\n \n-1. From the Conditional Access Optimization Agent page, select the **Settings** tab. \n+1. Browse to the **Settings** tab from the Conditional Access Optimization Agent.\n 1. Adjust the days between phases in the **Phased rollout** section.\n 1. Select the **Save** button to apply the changes.\n \n-For more information, review the [Phased rollout settings](agent-optimization.md#phased-rollout-preview).\n+For more information, review the [Phased rollout settings](agent-optimization.md#phased-rollout).\n+\n+## Agent or administrator executes the approved rollout plan\n+\n+The options available to manage the phased rollout are different for automatic and manual execution.\n+\n+### Automatically roll out phases\n+\n+If you selected automatic rollout, the agent automatically executes the plan by creating a new, enabled policy that applies to all groups in the first phase. Once the rollout starts, several controls appear to manage the rollout.\n+\n+The agent deploys the policy to the groups in the next phases based on the defined schedule. At any time during the phased rollout, you can pause the execution of the plan or choose to manually roll out the remaining phases.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-automatic-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of an automatically executed phased rollout.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-automatic-details.png\":::\n \n-### Agent executes the approved rollout plan\n+You can continue to monitor between each phase of the rollout to ensure the policy does what's expected. While the policy is being rolled out, the original report-only policy remains in report-only mode for the remaining phases. After the phased rollout is complete, the agent recommends deleting the report-only policy the next time it runs, so you can maintain a clean policy list.\n \n-The agent automatically executes the plan by creating a new, enabled policy that applies to all groups in the first phase. The original report-only policy remains intact so you can continue to collect data on the policy.\n+### Manually roll out phases\n \n-The agent deploys the policy to the groups in the next phases based on the defined schedule. You can continue to monitor between each phase of the rollout to ensure the policy does what's expected. While the policy is being rolled out, the policy remains in report-only mode for the remaining phases. \n+If you chose to manually execute the phased rollout plan, you're provided several options to manage each step.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-in-progress.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout that's in progress.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-in-progress.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-manual-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout plan in manual execution mode.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-manual-details.png\":::\n \n-After every phase is complete, the agent will recommend deleting the report-only policy the next time it runs, so you can maintain a clean policy list.\n+You must select the **Move to next phase** to advance each phase of the rollout. At any phase, you can revert to the previous phase or opt to have the agent automatically roll out the remaining phases.\n \n ## Built-in safeguards\n \n@@ -96,7 +115,7 @@ Once the phased rollout begins, you can't update the policy's grant controls. If\n \n ### How does the phased rollout capability work?\n \n-After selecting the groups that each phase will apply to, the agent creates a duplicate Conditional Access policy that only includes the group of the first phase. The original Conditional Access policy persists in report-only mode and targets all users, so you can continue to collect data. When the deployment advances to the next phase, the batch of groups is added to the enabled Conditional Access policy. The agent monitors how each stage affects the sign-ins associated with this policy. If the success rate drops below 90%, the phased rollout stops and the enabled policy is placed back into report-only mode. You can then review the logs to determine why sign-ins were failing before attempting the phased rollout again.\n+After selecting the groups that each phase applies to, the agent creates a duplicate Conditional Access policy that only includes the group of the first phase. The original Conditional Access policy persists in report-only mode and targets all users, so you can continue to collect data. When the deployment advances to the next phase, the batch of groups is added to the enabled Conditional Access policy. The agent monitors how each stage affects the sign-ins associated with this policy. If the success rate drops below 90%, the phased rollout stops and the enabled policy is placed back into report-only mode. You can then review the logs to determine why sign-ins were failing before attempting the phased rollout again.\n \n ### Do I have to turn on phased rollout?\n "

    "patch": "@@ -6,7 +6,7 @@ author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n \n-ms.date: 08/12/2025\n+ms.date: 08/28/2025\n \n ms.update-cycle: 180-days\n ms.service: entra-id\n@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ The Conditional Access optimization agent helps you ensure all users and applica\n The Conditional Access optimization agent evaluates policies such as requiring multifactor authentication (MFA), enforcing device based controls (device compliance, app protection policies, and domain-joined devices), and blocking legacy authentication and device code flow. The agent also evaluates all existing enabled policies to propose potential consolidation of similar policies. When the agent identifies a suggestion, you can have the agent update the associated policy with one click-remediation.\n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n-> The chat capability in the Conditional Access optimization agent is currently in PREVIEW.\n+> The chat capability and policy reports in the Conditional Access optimization agent are currently in PREVIEW.\n > This information relates to a prerelease product that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n@@ -38,7 +38,6 @@ The Conditional Access optimization agent evaluates policies such as requiring m\n    - For more information, see [Assign Security Copilot access](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access).\n - Device-based controls require [Microsoft Intune licenses](/intune/intune-service/fundamentals/licenses).\n - Review [Privacy and data security in Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/privacy-data-security).\n-\n    \n ### Limitations\n \n@@ -78,6 +77,7 @@ The policy suggestions identified by the agent include:\n - **Risky users**: The agent suggests a policy to require secure password change for high risk users. Requires Microsoft Entra ID P2 license.\n - **Risky sign-ins**: The agent suggests a policy to require multifactor authentication for high risk sign-ins. Requires Microsoft Entra ID P2 license.\n - **Policy consolidation**: The agent scans your policy and identifies overlapping settings. For example, if you have more than one policy that has the same grant controls, the agent suggests consolidating those policies into one.\n+- **Deep analysis**: The agent looks at policies that correspond to key scenarios to identify outlier policies that have more than a recommended number of exceptions (leading to unexpected gaps in coverage) or no exceptions (leading to possible lockout). \n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n > The agent doesn't make any changes to existing policies unless an administrator explicitly approves the suggestion.\n@@ -132,11 +132,11 @@ Use the checkboxes under **Microsoft Entra objects to monitor** to specify what\n \n By default, the Conditional Access optimization agent can create new policies in report-only mode. You can change this setting so that an administrator must approve the new policy before it's created. The policy is still created in report-only mode, but only after admin approval. After reviewing the policy impact, you can turn on the policy directly from the agent experience or from Conditional Access.\n \n-### Phased rollout (preview)\n+### Phased rollout\n \n When the agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, the policy is rolled out in phases, so you can control and monitor the effect of the new policy. Phased rollout is on by default.\n \n-You can change the number of days between each phase by either dragging the slider or entering a number of days in the text box. After making any changes, select the **Save** button at the bottom of the page. The number of days between each phase is the same for all phases. Make sure you're starting the phased rollout with enough time to monitor the impact before the next phase starts and so the rollout doesn't start on a weekend or holiday, in case you need to pause the rollout.\n+You can change the number of days between each phase by either dragging the slider or entering a number in the text box. After making any changes, select the **Save** button at the bottom of the page. The number of days between each phase is the same for all phases. Make sure you're starting the phased rollout with enough time to monitor the impact before the next phase starts and so the rollout doesn't start on a weekend or holiday, in case you need to pause the rollout.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phased rollout settings in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\":::\n \n@@ -150,7 +150,7 @@ There are several key points to consider regarding the identity and permissions\n - The user who approves a suggestion to add users to a policy becomes an owner of a new group that adds the users to a policy. \n - The audit logs for actions taken by the agent are associated with the user who enabled the agent. You can find the name of the account that started the agent in the **Identity and permissions** section of the settings.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the identity and permissions section in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\":::\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the identity and permissions section in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\":::\n \n ### Custom instructions\n \n@@ -174,6 +174,14 @@ For more information about how to use custom instructions, check out the followi\n \n Please note that some of the content in the video, such as the user interface elements, is subject to change as the agent is updated frequently.\n \n+## Intune integration\n+\n+The Conditional Access Optimization Agent integrates with Microsoft Intune to monitor application protection policies configured in Intune and identify potential gaps in Conditional Access enforcement. This proactive and automated approach ensures that Conditional Access policies remain aligned with organizational security goals and compliance requirements. The agent suggestions are the same as the other policy suggestions, except that Intune provides part of the signal to the agent.\n+\n+Agent suggestions for Intune scenarios cover specific user groups and platforms (iOS or Android). For example, the agent identifies an active Intune app protection policy that targets the \"Finance\" group, but determines there isn't a sufficient Conditional Access policy that enforces app protection. The agent creates a report-only policy that requires users to access resources only through compliant applications on iOS devices.\n+\n+The agent must be running as a Security Administrator or Global Administrator to identify Intune app protection policies. The Conditional Access Administrator role doesn't have sufficient privileges in Intune.\n+\n ## Remove agent\n \n If you no longer wish to use the Conditional Access optimization agent, select **Remove agent** from the top of the agent window. The existing data (agent activity, suggestions, and metrics) is removed but any policies created or updated based on the agent suggestions remain intact. Previously applied suggestions remain unchanged so you can continue to use the policies created or modified by the agent."

ai_summary.Response:
The document updates primarily focus on enhancing clarity and accuracy across several Microsoft Entra documentation pages.

Firstly, changes have been made to the "Tenant Restrictions v2" documentation, refining the steps for adding external users and groups.

Secondly, the "Copilot for Security with Microsoft Entra ID" documentation has been significantly updated, with a focus on improving the prompts and examples for investigating risky applications and service principals. The date has also been advanced.

Thirdly, minor edits have been made to the "Access Review Agent Logs and Metrics" and "Access Review Agent" documentation, including an image alt-text correction and the addition of language support information for the agent.

Finally, extensive revisions have been made to the "Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout" documentation. This includes removing the "preview" label, expanding on the phased rollout process, adding new screenshots, and detailing the automatic and manual execution of rollout plans. Additionally, the "Conditional Access optimization agent" documentation has been updated to reflect the removal of the "preview" label for chat capabilities, the addition of "deep analysis" as a suggestion type, and the inclusion of Intune integration details. Minor adjustments have also been made to the TOC.

Preview features are added frequently.\n \n+### Access Review Agent\n+\n+Empower your reviewers to make fast, accurate access decisions. The [Access Review Agent](../id-governance/access-review-agent.md) delivers insights and recommendations so reviewers can complete their work through a simple conversation, right inside Microsoft Teams.\n+\n+|Attribute  |Description  |\n+|---------|---------|\n+|Trigger     |   Runs every 24 hours or manually to gather insights and save recommendations.      |\n+|Permissions     | The agent reviews users currently in the scope of your access reviews, and makes suggestions on whether access should be approved or declined. The agent evaluates your current policy configuration against Microsoft best practices and Zero Trust principles."

  {
    "sha": "673a5a8538572ee9acf79bf476f96980038cc7ab",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/access-review-agent-logs-metrics.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 72,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 72,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent-logs-metrics.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent-logs-metrics.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent-logs-metrics.md?ref=bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,72 @@\n+---\n+title: Logs and metrics for the Access Review Agent (Preview)\n+description: Learn about the logs and metrics of the Access Review Agent.\n+author: owinfreyATL\n+ms.author: owinfrey\n+ms.service: entra-id-governance\n+ms.subservice: access-reviews\n+ms.topic: how-to #Required; leave this attribute/value as-is\n+ms.date: 09/04/2025\n+\n+#CustomerIntent: As a governance administrator, I want to view the logs and metrics for access reviews completed with help from the access review agent.\n+---\n+\n+# View logs and metrics for the Access Review Agent (Preview)\n+\n+The Access Review Agent helps organizations improve their security posture by automatically analyzing sign-in patterns and suggesting policy optimizations. This Microsoft Security Copilot agent identifies unprotected users and applications, recommends policy improvements, and helps consolidate redundant policies.\n+\n+To ensure transparency and maintain control over automated recommendations, Microsoft Entra ID provides comprehensive logging and metrics for all agent activities. This article explains how to monitor agent performance, review audit logs, and understand the metrics that help you measure the agent's impact on your security environment.\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+- To view the Microsoft Entra audit logs, you need at least the [Reports reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#reports-reader) role.\n+- To view the overview, activities, or settings of the Access Review Agent you must have at least **all** the following roles:\n+   - [Identity Governance  Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator)\n+   - [Lifecycle Workflows Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#lifecycle-workflows-administrator)\n+   - [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access)\n+- Review [Privacy and data security in Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/privacy-data-security).\n+\n+\n+## Agent Summary\n+\n+To view information about the Access Review Agent, open up the Access Review Agent to get to the overview page. The highlight of the overview page is the Agent summary, which provides a quick summary of agent actions over the course of the last 30 days.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-review-agent-overview.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the overview screen in the Access Review Agent overview.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-review-agent-overview.png\":::\n+\n+\n+The **Agent Summary** shows:\n+\n+- **Total access reviews**: The number of access reviews that are reviewed by the agent.\n+- **Total decisions analyzed**: The number of decisions made by the agent.\n+- **Total reviewers**: The number of reviewers who used the agent to complete access reviews.\n+- **Security compute units used**: The number of [security compute units (SCU)](/copilot/security/manage-usage) consumed by the agent to analyze identified reviews by gathering extra insights and generates recommendations (approve / deny) and justification summaries for each decision. This number does **not** include the SCUs consumed by the natural language conversation between reviewers and the agent. \n+\n+\n+The overview page also includes other general information about the agent such as its latest activity, and whether its currently active.\n+\n+## Agent Activities\n+\n+From the overview page, you can select the **Activities** tab to view a full list of the activities of the Access Review Agent. A run is generated for each active access review instance the agent analyzes. A run is also generated if the agent hasn't identified any new active access review instances to analyze. Each access review instance is analyzed once and generates a signal run. \n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-review-agents-activities.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a list of activities in the Access Review Agent.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-review-agents-activities.png\":::\n+\n+For each activity, you can see:\n+\n+- The date and time the run started\n+- The number of SCU used\n+- The number of reviewers involved in the review to which the run corresponds\n+- The status of the run\n+\n+### View Agent's Full Activity\n+\n+To see a detailed summary of the agent's activity, the recommendations (approve / deny), and the justification summaries it generated, select **View activity** next to the specific activity.\n+\n+The **Summary of agent activity** is a natural language description of the activity illustrated in the **Agent activity map**. These details help you understand the logic behind the agent and you can view the recommendations and justification summaries on the last card in the activity map.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of Access Review Agent justification in activity card.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\":::\n+\n+\n+## Related content\n+\n+- [Access Review Agent with Microsoft Security Copilot](access-review-agent.md)\n+- [What are access reviews?](access-reviews-overview.md)"
  },
  {
    "sha": "14790eabb1f3bd12d577766d9ec235a4ac6ea770",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/access-review-agent.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 228,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 228,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md?ref=bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,228 @@\n+---\n+title: Microsoft Security Copilot Access Review Agent in Microsoft Entra\n+description: Learn how the Access Review Agent, with Microsoft Security Copilot, can help secure your organization through recommendations based on your data.\n+author: owinfreyATL\n+ms.author: owinfrey\n+ms.service: entra-id-governance\n+ms.subservice: access-reviews\n+ms.topic: how-to #Required; leave this attribute/value as-is\n+ms.date: 09/04/2025\n+\n+#CustomerIntent: As a Security Administrator, I want to set up the Access Review Agent so that Security Copilot can be used to help complete access reviews for users in my organization.\n+---\n+\n+# Access Review Agent\n+Say goodbye to time-consuming research and the uncertainty of rushed decisions. The Access Review Agent works for your reviewers by automatically gathering insights and generating recommendations. It then guides reviewers through the review process in Microsoft Teams with natural language, with simple summaries and proposed decisions, so they can make the final call with confidence and clarity.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-prompt.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the initial prompt in the access review agent chat.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-prompt.png\":::\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+- You must have [Microsoft Entra ID Governance or Microsoft Entra Suitelicenses](licensing-fundamentals.md).\n+- You must [Onboard to Security Copilot](/copilot/security/get-started-security-copilot#onboarding-to-security-copilot) with at least one [security compute unit (SCU)](/copilot/security/manage-usage) provisioned.\n+   - Completing an access review that includes 20 decisions consumes on average one SCU. This includes the agent gathering insights and generating recommendations and the reviewer's natural language conversation in Microsoft Teams with the agent. The SCU consumption can vary based on the conversation length between the reviewer and agent.\n+- Admins must have at least **all** the following roles to set up and manage the agent in the Microsoft Entra admin center:\n+   - [Identity Governance  Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator)\n+   - [Lifecycle Workflows Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#lifecycle-workflows-administrator)\n+   - [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access)\n+- For reviewers to use the Access Review Agent, they must have access to Microsoft Teams and must have an active access review assigned to them. They must also have at least the [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access) role assigned to them.\n+- Review [Privacy and data security in Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/privacy-data-security)\n+\n+### Limitations\n+- Avoid using an account to set up the agent that requires role activation with Privileged Identity Management (PIM). Using an account that doesn't have standing permissions can cause authentication failures for the agent.\n+- Once agents are started, they can't be stopped or paused. It might take a few minutes to run.\n+- The agent runs using the identity of the administrator who activated it for the first time to gather insights and save recommendations. Final decisions, as part of the Microsoft Teams conversation, is written with the reviewers identity.\n+- We recommend running the agent from the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n+\n+## Supported Scenarios\n+The following tables show current Access Review Agent support based on review scenarios:\n+\n+| Scenario |Supported  |\n+|---------|---------|\n+|**Resources**  |  |\n+|Teams + Groups     |   :white_check_mark:       |\n+|Access package assignment     |    :white_check_mark:      |\n+|Application assignment        |   :white_check_mark:       |\n+|Azure resource roles          |                            |\n+|Microsoft Entra roles         |                            |\n+|Groups managed by Privileged Identity Management         |                            |\n+|**Size**  |  |\n+|Up to 35 decisions (per review, not reviewer)     |  :white_check_mark:       |\n+|>35 decisions per review     |          |\n+|**Stages**  |  |\n+|Single Stage     |  :white_check_mark:       |\n+|Multi-stage     |          |\n+|**Reviewers**  |  |\n+|Specific     |   :white_check_mark:       |\n+|Group owners     |  :white_check_mark:        |\n+|Managers     |  :white_check_mark:        |\n+|Self-reviews     |      |\n+\n+## How it works\n+The Access Review Agent proactively scans for active access reviews in your tenant that are flagged for processing by the agent. The agent then analyzes identified reviews by gathering extra insights, and generates a recommendation (approve / deny) and a justification summary for each decision. Once the agent analyzes the recommendations and corresponding justification summaries, it's able to guide reviewers, in natural language, through the review process in Microsoft Teams. Reviewers are empowered to complete their reviews through the natural language chat experience in Microsoft Teams. As the agent guides them through the review, they're able to review the agent's reasoning behind the recommendations, ask questions in the context of the review itself, and finally make their own informed decision.\n+\n+The agents recommendation (approve / deny) for each decision relies on a deterministic scoring mechanism powered by multiple signals. The signals used for the recommendation are then used to provide an end-user friendly justification summary powered by a large language model (LLM). The subsequent natural language chat experience in Microsoft Teams is facilitated by the large language model with previously generated recommendations and justification summaries as available context.\n+\n+The agent considers the following signals:\n+\n+- **User inactivity**: If the user has [signed in](review-recommendations-access-reviews.md#inactive-user-recommendations)\n+- **User-to-Group affiliation**: If the user has a [low affiliation](review-recommendations-access-reviews.md#user-to-group-affiliation) with other users who have this access\n+- **Account enabled**: If the user's account is enabled (accountEnabled property)\n+- **Employment status**: If the user's employment ended ([employeeLeaveDateTime property](/graph/tutorial-lifecycle-workflows-set-employeeleavedatetime))\n+- **Lifecycle workflow history**: If the user has had a mover workflow ran for them in the past 30 days\n+- **Decisions from previous reviews**: For recurring reviews, decisions from previous review iterations are considered\n+- **Access request history**: For access package assignment reviews, the request and approval history is considered\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> The justification summary includes information from these signals and is available to the reviewer during the review process even though some of this information isn't available to reviewers outside of the review process.\n+\n+As an admin you're able to review the recommendations (approve / deny) and justification summaries. For details see, [Access Review Agent logs and metrics (Preview)](access-review-agent-logs-metrics.md). Note the agent recommendations can differ from the recommendations shown on the My Access portal and Access Review experience in the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n+\n+## Getting started\n+### Setting up the Access Review Agent\n+1. With an account that has at least **all** the following roles, sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com):\n+   - [Identity Governance  Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator)\n+   - [Lifecycle Workflows Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#lifecycle-workflows-administrator)\n+   - [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access)\n+1. From the new home page, select **Go to agents** from the agent notification card.\n+   - You can also select **Agents** from the left navigation menu.\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent/start-access-review-agent.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of starting the Access Review Agent.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent/start-access-review-agent.png\":::\n+1. Select **View details** on the Access Review Agent tile.\n+    \n+1. Select **Start agent** to begin your first run. \n+   - Avoid using an account with a role activated through PIM.\n+   - A message that says \"*The agent is starting its first run*\" appears in the upper-right corner.\n+   - The first run might take a few minutes to complete.\n+\n+### Enable the access review agent for existing access reviews\n+\n+After the Access Review Agent is started, you must flag access reviews to be processed by the Access Review Agent. The Access Review Agent is able to process both new, and existing, access reviews. The following sections walk you through flagging access review to be processed by the Access Review Agent.\n+\n+#### Enable the access review agent for existing group and application access reviews\n+\n+To update an existing access review to be processed by the Access Review Agent, perform the following steps:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Access reviews**.\n+\n+1. Select the access review you want the agent to support.\n+\n+1. On the access review overview page, select **Settings** under Manage if it's a one time review, or **Settings** under Series if it's a recurring review.\n+\n+1. Under **Advanced Settings**, check the box on the setting that says **Access Review Agent (Preview)**.\n+\n+1. Select **Save**. \n+\n+#### Enable the Access Review Agent for existing access package assignment reviews\n+\n+To update an existing access review to be processed by the Access Review Agent, perform the following steps:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Entitlement management** > **Access package**.\n+\n+1. Select the access package you want the agent to support.\n+\n+1. On the access package overview page, select **Policies**, then select the policy you want to update and select **Edit**.\n+\n+1. On the edit policy page, select **Lifecycle**.\n+\n+1. On the lifecycle tab, select Advanced Access Review settings and check the **Enable** box on the setting that says **Access Review Agent (Preview)**.\n+\n+1. Select **Save**.    \n+\n+### Ensure reviewers can use the Access Review Agent\n+\n+Reviewers access the Access Review Agent through a [Microsoft Teams App](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3). If your organizations' [Microsoft Teams org-wide app settings](/microsoftteams/manage-apps#manage-org-wide-app-settings) allow Microsoft applications no action is required. If your organization has disabled Microsoft apps in the Microsoft Teams org-wide app settings your organizations' Microsoft Teams administrator must explicitly approve the app.\n+\n+You must also ensure that all reviewers have at least the [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access) role so that they can use the agent to complete their reviews. This is required because the natural language conversation in Microsoft Teams is opening a Microsoft Security Copilot session behind the scenes. Participating reviewers access the agentic experience via Microsoft Teams, but with the role assignment they'll be entitled to access the [Security Copilot portal](https://securitycopilot.microsoft.com/) or the Security Copilot experience in other Microsoft Security administrative portals. If reviewers access Security Copilot outside of Microsoft Teams, their data access with Security Copilot is still subject to [default user permissions](../fundamentals/users-default-permissions.md).\n+\n+## Using the Access Review Agent as a reviewer\n+\n+With the Access Review Agent started, reviewers assigned proper permissions, and with the app available to them, your reviewers are now ready to complete their reviews with the help of the agent. The Access Review Agent can be accessed directly within Microsoft Teams ([direct link](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3)). The access review email notifications sent to reviewers will also include a direct link to Microsoft Teams.\n+\n+1. Open your Microsoft Teams application signed in as the user assigned as a reviewer.\n+\n+1. Select the [Access Review Agent](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3) link to open the agent\n+\n+1. On the Apps page, search **Access Review Agent**, and select **Add**.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-teams.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Access Review Agent application in Microsoft Teams.\":::\n+1. Once the agent is added, select **Open**.\n+1. When open, you can select the available prompt to start the chat with the agent\n+     :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-prompt.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the initial prompt in the access review agent chat.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-prompt.png\":::\n+\n+## Settings\n+\n+Once the agent is enabled, you can adjust a few settings. You can access the settings by doing the following in the Microsoft Entra admin center:\n+\n+- From **Agents** > **Access Review Agent** > **Settings**.\n+\n+### Trigger\n+\n+The agent is configured to run every 24 hours based on when it's initially configured. You can run it at a specific time by toggling the **Trigger** setting off, and then back on when you want it to run.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent/access-review-agent-trigger.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Access Review Agent trigger.\":::\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> If reviewers immediately respond to their access review email notifications, the agent might not have yet processed the review. Only after the agent runs is it able to assist with access reviews in Microsoft Teams. If you respond before the agent processes the review, the agent responds with the following message to the reviewer in Microsoft Teams: '*I don't see any pending reviews that I can help you with at this time. Because my capabilities are still expanding, I recommend you check the My Access Portal to see if you have any other pending reviews.*'\n+\n+## Removing the agent \n+\n+If you no longer wish to use the Access Review Agent, select **Remove agent** from the top of the agent window. The existing agent activity and metrics are removed but recommendations and justifications for already processed reviews are retained by the agent in Microsoft Teams and continue to be able to assist reviewers with these reviews. To complete the removal, you should also unflag the access reviews previously flagged to be processed by the agent.\n+\n+### Disable the access review agent for existing group and application access reviews\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Access Reviews**.\n+\n+1. Select the access review that has agent support enabled.\n+\n+1. On the access review overview page, select **Settings** under Manage if it's a one time review, or **Settings** under Series if it's a recurring review.\n+\n+1. Under **Advanced Settings**, uncheck the box on the setting that says **Access Review Agent (Preview)**.\n+\n+1. Select **Save**. \n+\n+### Disable the Access Review Agent for existing access package assignment reviews\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Entitlement management** > **Access package**.\n+\n+1. Select the access package you want the agent to support.\n+\n+1. On the access package overview page, select **Policies**, then select the policy you want to update and select **Edit**.\n+\n+1. On the edit policy page, select **Lifecycle**.\n+\n+1. On the lifecycle tab, check the **Disable** box on the setting that says **Access Review Agent (Preview)**.\n+\n+1. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Revoke Security Copilot access\n+\n+You might want to revoke the [Security Copilot Contributor](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access) access of reviewers if no other scenario requires them to access Security Copilot.\n+\n+## Identity and permissions\n+The agent runs with the identity of the administrator who configured the agent to gather insights and save recommendations. Final decisions as part of the Microsoft Teams conversation will be written with the reviewers identity.\n+\n+### Providing feedback\n+\n+Use the **Give Microsoft feedback** button at the top of the agent window to provide feedback to Microsoft about the agent.\n+\n+## FAQs\n+\n+**Why is the agent in Microsoft Teams responding with 'It looks like the Access Review Agent either has not yet been enabled for your organization or has encountered unexpected issues. Please contact your IT department for assistance. In the meantime, you can complete your pending reviews in the My Access Portal'?**\n+\n+If the agent responds with this message, it's likely the agent setup such as starting the agent, assigning reviewers Security Copilot access, and enabling the agent for existing reviews, isn't completed. \n+\n+**Why is the agent in Microsoft Teams responding with 'Things are a bit busy at the moment, and I couldn't process your request right now. Could you please try again in a little while? If you're in a hurry, the My Access Portal is always available.'?**\n+\n+The agent responds with this message if your tenant is out of provisioned and overage Security Copilot capacity.\n+\n+## Related content\n+\n+- [Access Review Agent logs and metrics (Preview)](access-review-agent-logs-metrics.md)\n+- [Review recommendations for Access reviews](review-recommendations-access-reviews.md)\n+- [Learn more about Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/microsoft-security-copilot)"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -12,16 +12,33 @@ ms.author: owinfrey\n ---\n # Review access of an access package in entitlement management\n \n-Entitlement management simplifies how enterprises manage access to groups, applications, and SharePoint sites. This article describes how to perform access reviews for other users that are assigned to an access package as a designated reviewer.\n+Entitlement management simplifies how enterprises manage access to groups, applications, and SharePoint sites. This article describes how designated reviewers can review user assignments to access packages which grant the assigned users access.\n \n-## Prerequisites\n+You can review access package assignments via the [My Access portal](https://myaccess.microsoft.com/), or via chat with the [Access Review Agent (Preview)](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3) in Microsoft Teams. The Access Review Agent is currently in preview and does not yet support all types of access package assignment reviews, if the agent cannot yet help you with your assigned reviews it will guide you to the My Access portal.\n \n-[!INCLUDE [Microsoft Entra ID Governance license](../includes/entra-entra-governance-license.md)]\n+## Perform an access review using the Access Review Agent (Preview)\n+The Access Review Agent assists you in completing your pending access reviews by guiding you in Microsoft Teams with natural language, insights, and recommendations. To use the Access Review Agent to perform an access review, do the following:\n \n+### Go directly to the Access Review Agent\n+1. Select the [Access Review Agent](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3) link to open the agent.\n+1. Select **Add** or **Open** to access the conversation with the Access Review Agent.\n+1. Prompt the agent with **Help me with my access reviews** and the agent will assist you in completing your pending access reviews.\n \n-## Open the access review\n+### Use email to go to the Access Review Agent\n \n-As at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#identity-governance-administrator), use the following steps to find and open the access review:\n+>[!IMPORTANT]\n+> There could be delays in receiving email. In some cases, it could take up to 24 hours. Add MSSecurity-noreply@microsoft.com to your safe recipients list to make sure that you're receiving all emails.\n+1. Look for an email from Microsoft asking you to review access.\n+1. Select the **Review user access** link to open the [Access Review Agent](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3). The **Start review** link will either open the Access Review Agent or the My Access portal based on your organizations policies. If the link opens the My Access portal the Access Review Agent has not been enabled for the specific review and must be completed via the My Access portal.\n+1. Select **Add** or **Open** to access the conversation with the Access Review Agent\n+1. Prompt the agent with **Help me with my access reviews** and the agent will assist you in completing your pending access reviews.\n+\n+## Perform access review by using the My Access portal\n+The [My Access portal](https://myaccess.microsoft.com/) is a user-friendly portal for manually granting, approving, and reviewing access needs.\n+\n+### Open the access review\n+\n+Use the following steps to find and open the access review:\n \n 1. You could receive an email from Microsoft that asks you to review access. Locate the email to open the access review. Here's an example email to review access:\n     \n@@ -39,13 +56,7 @@ As at least an [Identity Governance Administrator](../identity/role-based-access\n     \n     ![Select the access review](./media/entitlement-management-access-reviews-review-access/review-access-select-access-review.png)\n \n-## Perform the access review\n-\n-Once you open the access review, you see the names of users for which you need to review. There are two ways that you can approve or deny access:\n-- You can manually approve or deny access for one or more users\n-- You can accept the system recommendations\n-\n-### Manually approve or deny access for one or more users\n+### Manually approve or deny access for one or more users using the My Access portal\n 1. Review the list of users and determine which users need to continue to have access.\n \n     ![List of users to review](./media/entitlement-management-access-reviews-review-access/review-access-list-of-users.png)"

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fperform-access-review.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fperform-access-review.md?ref=bf452a3bfc20f02abc94acecdccb50c8f801ee35",
    "patch": "@@ -17,8 +17,28 @@ ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n \n Microsoft Entra ID simplifies how enterprises manage access to groups and applications in Microsoft Entra ID and other Microsoft web services with a feature called access reviews. This article covers how a designated reviewer performs an access review for members of a group or users with access to an application. If you want to review access to an access package, read [Review access of an access package in entitlement management](entitlement-management-access-reviews-review-access.md).\n \n-## Perform access review by using My Access\n-You can review access to groups and applications via My Access. My Access is a user-friendly portal for granting, approving, and reviewing access needs.\n+You can review access to groups and applications via the [My Access portal](https://myaccess.microsoft.com/) or via chat with the [Access Review Agent (Preview)](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3) in Microsoft Teams. The Access Review Agent is currently in preview and does not yet support all types of group and application reviews, if the agent cannot yet help you with your assigned reviews it will guide you to the My Access portal.\n+\n+## Perform an access review using the Access Review Agent (Preview)\n+The Access Review Agent assists you in completing your pending access reviews by guiding you in Microsoft Teams with natural language, insights, and recommendations.\n+\n+### Go directly to the Access Review Agent\n+1. Select the [Access Review Agent](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3) link to open the agent\n+1. Select **Add** or **Open** to access the conversation with the Access Review Agent\n+1. Prompt the agent with **Help me with my access reviews** and the agent will assist you in completing your pending access reviews.\n+\n+### Use email to go to the Access Review Agent\n+\n+>[!IMPORTANT]\n+> There could be delays in receiving email. In some cases, it could take up to 24 hours. Add MSSecurity-noreply@microsoft.com to your safe recipients list to make sure that you're receiving all emails.\n+\n+1. Look for an email from Microsoft asking you to review access.\n+1. Select the **Start review** link to open the [Access Review Agent](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/app/b99caf01-1dd7-43cf-981a-0de444e783f3). The **Start review** link will either open the Access Review Agent or the My Access portal based on your organizations policies. If the link opens the My Access portal the Access Review Agent has not been enabled for the specific review and must be completed via the My Access portal.\n+1. Select **Add** or **Open** to access the conversation with the Access Review Agent\n+1. Prompt the agent with **Help me with my access reviews** and the agent will assist you in completing your pending access reviews.\n+\n+## Perform access review by using the My Access portal\n+The [My Access portal](https://myaccess.microsoft.com/) is a user-friendly portal for granting, approving, and reviewing access needs.\n \n ### Use email to go to My Access\n "

ai_summary.Response: The commit introduces the Access Review Agent, a new feature integrating Microsoft Security Copilot with Microsoft Entra ID to enhance access review processes. This agent provides insights and recommendations within Microsoft Teams to streamline reviewer decisions. Accompanying documentation details its setup, usage, limitations, and a new section for viewing agent logs and metrics. The changes also update table of contents and existing documentation to reflect the integration of this agent.

If Group SOA is converted for the group, or if cloud security group provisioning to AD DS is enabled, those local AD changes aren't reflected in Microsoft Entra ID. When a change to the cloud security group is made, any local AD DS changes are overwritten when group provisioning to AD DS runs.\n \n - **No dual write allowed**: After you start to manage the memberships for the converted group (say cloud group A) from Microsoft Entra ID, and you provision this group to AD as a nested group under another AD DS group (OnPremGroupB) that's in scope for sync to Microsoft Entra ID, the membership references of group A aren't synced when sync happens for OnPremGroupB. The membership references aren't synced because the sync client doesn't know the cloud group membership references. This behavior is by design.\n " } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

*   **Microsoft Entra Application Proxy:** The documentation for configuring custom domains has been updated, primarily to correct a formatting error in an example URL.
*   **Microsoft Entra Conditional Access:** Two new entries, "Copilot Data Platform" and "OneOutlook," have been added to the reference list of Office 365 applications.
*   **Microsoft Entra Hybrid Management:** The guide for configuring Group Source of Authority has undergone significant revisions. This includes updating the date, clarifying prerequisites for sync clients (both Connect Sync and Cloud Sync), and detailing the process for downloading and verifying these clients. Additionally, the limitations section has been rephrased for clarity regarding reconciliation support for AD DS groups and the absence of dual write capabilities.

{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "f23fabb889554073e133a5f78e39b098b16db2f0",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md",
    "status": "removed",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 134,
    "changes": 134,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/d07e44c441a4b4a74020802d688ab1833ad17d65/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/d07e44c441a4b4a74020802d688ab1833ad17d65/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-configure-threat-intelligence.md?ref=d07e44c441a4b4a74020802d688ab1833ad17d65",
    "patch": "@@ -1,134 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: How to configure Global Secure Access threat intelligence\n-description: Learn how to configure threat intelligence in Microsoft Entra Internet Access.\n-author: fgomulka\n-ms.author: frankgomulka\n-manager: ashishj\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 05/29/2025\n-ms.service: global-secure-access\n-ms.subservice: entra-internet-access\n-ms.reviewer: fgomulka\n----\n-\n-# How to configure Global Secure Access threat intelligence (preview)\n-\n-Threat intelligence empowers you to protect your users from accessing malicious destinations on the internet, based on real-time data on current threats. \n-\n-You can configure a threat intelligence policy to block users from high-severity known malicious internet destinations. In this policy, Microsoft Entra Internet Access blocks traffic based on domain and URL indicators from both Microsoft and third-party threat intelligence providers. With the threat intelligence rule engine, you can also configure allow lists for handling false positives. All of these policies can become context-aware with the Security Profile framework, linking Global Secure Access (GSA) security policies to Conditional Access. \n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-- Administrators who interact with **Global Secure Access** features must have one or more of the following role assignments depending on the tasks they're performing.\n-   - The [Global Secure Access Administrator role](/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference) role to manage the Global Secure Access features.\n-   - The [Conditional Access Administrator](/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference#conditional-access-administrator) to create and interact with Conditional Access policies.\n-- Complete the [Get started with Global Secure Access](how-to-get-started-with-global-secure-access.md) guide.\n-- [Install the Global Secure Access client](how-to-install-windows-client.md) on end user devices.\n-- You must disable Domain Name System (DNS) over HTTPS (Secure DNS) to tunnel network traffic. Use the rules of the fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) in the traffic forwarding profile. For more information, see [Configure the DNS client to support DoH](/windows-server/networking/dns/doh-client-support#configure-the-dns-client-to-support-doh).\n-- Disable built-in DNS client on Chrome and Microsoft Edge.\n-- IPv6 traffic isn't acquired by the client and is therefore transferred directly to the network. To enable all relevant traffic to be tunneled, set the network adapter properties to [IPv4 preferred](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md#ipv4-preferred).\n-- User Datagram Protocol (UDP) traffic (that is, QUIC) isn't supported in the current preview of Internet Access. Most websites support fallback to Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) when QUIC can't be established. For an improved user experience, you can deploy a Windows Firewall rule that blocks outbound UDP 443: \n-\n-```powershell \n-@New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName \"Block QUIC\" -Direction Outbound -Action Block -Protocol UDP  -RemotePort 443\n-``` \n-\n-- (Optional) [Configure Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection](how-to-transport-layer-security.md) in order for URL indicators to be evaluated against HTTPS traffic.\n-\n-## High level steps\n-\n-There are several steps to configuring threat intelligence. Take note of where you need to configure a Conditional Access policy.\n-\n-1. [Enable internet traffic forwarding.](#enable-internet-traffic-forwarding)\n-1. [Create a threat intelligence policy.](#create-a-threat-intelligence-policy)\n-1. [Configure your allow list (optional).](#configure-your-allow-list-optional)\n-1. [Create a security profile.](#create-a-security-profile-or-configure-the-baseline-profile)\n-1. [Link the security profile to a Conditional Access policy.](#create-and-link-conditional-access-policy)\n-\n-## Enable internet traffic forwarding\n-\n-The first step is to enable the Internet Access traffic forwarding profile. To learn more about the profile and how to enable it, see [How to manage the Internet Access traffic forwarding profile](how-to-manage-internet-access-profile.md).\n-\n-You can scope the Internet Access profile to specific users and groups. To learn more about user and group assignment, see [How to assign and manage users and groups with traffic forwarding profiles](how-to-manage-users-groups-assignment.md).\n-\n-## Create a threat intelligence policy\n-\n-1. Browse to **Global Secure Access** > **Secure** > **Threat Intelligence Policies**.\n-1. Select **Create policy**.\n-1. Enter a name and description for the policy and select **Next**.\n-1. The default action for threat intelligence is \"Allow\". This means that if traffic doesn't match a rule in the threat intelligence policy, the policy engine will allow the traffic to go to the next security control.\n-1. Select **Next** and **Review** your new threat intelligence policy.\n-1. Select **Create**\n-\n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> This policy is created with a rule blocking access to destinations where high severity threats are detected. Microsoft defines high severity threats as domains or URLs associated with active malware distribution, phishing campaigns, command-and-control (C2) infrastructure, and other threads, identified by Microsoft and third-party threat intelligence feeds with high confidence.\n-\n-## Configure your allow list (optional)\n-\n-If you're aware of sites that may be business-critical or are labeled as false positives, you can configure rules that allow these sites. Note the security risks involved with this action, as the internet threat landscape is ever-changing.\n-\n-1. Under **Global Secure Access** > **Secure** > **Threat Intelligence Policies**, select your chosen threat intelligence policy.\n-1. Select **Rules**.\n-1. Select **Add rule**.\n-1. Enter a name, description, priority, and status for the rule.\n-1. Edit **Destination FQDNs** and select the list of domains for your allow list. You can enter these FQDNs as comma-separated domains.\n-1. Select **Add**. \n-\n-## Create a security profile or configure the baseline profile\n-\n-Security profiles are a grouping of security controls like web content filtering and threat intelligence policies. You can assign, or link, security profiles with Microsoft Entra Conditional Access policies. One security profile can contain a policy of each type.\n-\n-In this step, you create a security profile to group filtering policies like web content filtering and/or threat intelligence. Then you assign, or link, the security profiles with a Conditional Access policy to make them user or context aware.\n-\n-Since threat intelligence is critical for users' basic security posture, you can alternatively link your threat intelligence policy to the baseline security profile, which applies policy to all users' traffic in your tenant.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> You can only configure threat intelligence policy per security profile. Rule priorities within each security control handle exceptions, and security controls follow the ordering, (1) TLS inspection > (2) Web content filtering > (3) Threat intelligence > (4) File type > (6) Data loss prevention > (7) Third-party\n-\n-1. Browse to **Global Secure Access** > **Secure** > **Security profiles**.\n-2. Select **Create profile**.\n-3. Enter a name and description for the profile and select **Next**.\n-4. Select **Link a policy** and then select **Existing threat intelligence policy**.\n-5. Select the threat intelligence policy you already created and select **Add**.\n-6. Select **Next** to review the security profile and associated policy.\n-7. Select **Create profile**.\n-8. Select **Refresh** to view the new profile.\n-\n-## Create and link Conditional Access policy\n-\n-Create a Conditional Access policy for end users or groups and deliver your security profile through Conditional Access Session controls. Conditional Access is the delivery mechanism for user and context awareness for Internet Access policies.\n-\n-1. Browse to **Identity** > **Protection** > **Conditional Access**.\n-2. Select **Create new policy**.\n-3. Enter a name and assign a user or group.\n-4. Select **Target resources** and **All internet resources with Global Secure Access**.\n-5. Select **Session** > **Use Global Secure Access security profile** and choose a security profile.\n-6. Select **Select**.\n-7. In the **Enable policy** section, ensure **On** is selected.\n-8. Select **Create**.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Applying a new security profile can take up to 60-90 minutes because security profiles are enforced via access tokens.\n-\n-\n-## Verify end user policy enforcement\n-\n-Use a Windows device with the Global Secure Access client installed. Sign in as a user that is assigned the Internet traffic acquisition profile. Test that navigating to malicious websites is blocked as expected.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> After configuring a threat intelligence policy, you may need to [clear your browser's cache](https://www.microsoft.com/edge/learning-center/how-to-manage-and-clear-your-cache-and-cookies) to validate policy enforcement.\n-\n-1. Right-click on the Global Secure Access client icon in the task manager tray and open **Advanced Diagnostics** > **Forwarding profile**. Ensure that the Internet access acquisition rules are present.\n-1. Navigate to a known malicious site (for example, `entratestthreat.com` or `smartscreentestratings2.net`). Ensure that you're blocked and that the Threat Type field is nonempty in the traffic logs. Traffic logs may take up to 5 minutes to appear in the portal.\n-1. If blocked by Windows Defender or Smart screen, override and access the site to test the Global Secure Access block message. You can do this by choosing \"Continue to the unsafe site (not recommended)\" under \"More information.\"\n-1. To test allow-listing, create a rule in the Threat Intelligence policy to allow access to the site. Within 2 minutes, you should be able to access it. (You may need to clear your browser cache.)\n-1. Evaluate the rest of the threat feed against your known threat indicators.\n-\n-![Screenshot showing a plaintext browser error for unencrypted or TLS inspected HTTP traffic.](media/how-to-configure-threat-intelligence/http-block-ti.png)\n-\n-> [!CAUTION]\n-> Testing with real malicious sites should be performed in a sandbox or test environment to protect your device and enterprise.\n-\n-## Next steps\n-\n-- [Learn about the traffic dashboard](concept-traffic-dashboard.md)"

ai_summary.Response: The documentation for Microsoft Entra Internet Access has been updated. The article on configuring threat intelligence has been removed entirely, likely due to a deprecation or significant restructuring of the feature. Minor updates have been made to the web content filtering documentation, including adding a note about deployment times and correcting an image reference. Additionally, the table of contents has been adjusted to reflect the removal of the threat intelligence article.

    "patch": "@@ -1,134 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: How to configure Global Secure Access threat intelligence\n-description: Learn how to configure threat intelligence in Microsoft Entra Internet Access.\n-author: fgomulka\n-ms.author: frankgomulka\n-manager: ashishj\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 05/29/2025\n-ms.service: global-secure-access\n-ms.subservice: entra-internet-access\n-ms.reviewer: fgomulka\n----\n-\n-# How to configure Global Secure Access threat intelligence (preview)\n-\n-Threat intelligence empowers you to protect your users from accessing malicious destinations on the internet, based on real-time data on current threats. \n-\n-You can configure a threat intelligence policy to block users from high-severity known malicious internet destinations. In this policy, Microsoft Entra Internet Access blocks traffic based on domain and URL indicators from both Microsoft and third-party threat intelligence providers. With the threat intelligence rule engine, you can also configure allow lists for handling false positives. All of these policies can become context-aware with the Security Profile framework, linking Global Secure Access (GSA) security policies to Conditional Access. \n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-- Administrators who interact with **Global Secure Access** features must have one or more of the following role assignments depending on the tasks they're performing.\n-   - The [Global Secure Access Administrator role](/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference) role to manage the Global Secure Access features.\n-   - The [Conditional Access Administrator](/azure/active-directory/roles/permissions-reference#conditional-access-administrator) to create and interact with Conditional Access policies.\n-- Complete the [Get started with Global Secure Access](how-to-get-started-with-global-secure-access.md) guide.\n-- [Install the Global Secure Access client](how-to-install-windows-client.md) on end user devices.\n-- You must disable Domain Name System (DNS) over HTTPS (Secure DNS) to tunnel network traffic. Use the rules of the fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) in the traffic forwarding profile. For more information, see [Configure the DNS client to support DoH](/windows-server/networking/dns/doh-client-support#configure-the-dns-client-to-support-doh).\n-- Disable built-in DNS client on Chrome and Microsoft Edge.\n-- IPv6 traffic isn't acquired by the client and is therefore transferred directly to the network. To enable all relevant traffic to be tunneled, set the network adapter properties to [IPv4 preferred](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md#ipv4-preferred).\n-- User Datagram Protocol (UDP) traffic (that is, QUIC) isn't supported in the current preview of Internet Access. Most websites support fallback to Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) when QUIC can't be established. For an improved user experience, you can deploy a Windows Firewall rule that blocks outbound UDP 443: \n-\n-```powershell \n-@New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName \"Block QUIC\" -Direction Outbound -Action Block -Protocol UDP  -RemotePort 443\n-``` \n-\n-- (Optional) [Configure Transport Layer Security (TLS) inspection](how-to-transport-layer-security.md) in order for URL indicators to be evaluated against HTTPS traffic.\n-\n-## High level steps\n-\n-There are several steps to configuring threat intelligence. Take note of where you need to configure a Conditional Access policy.\n-\n-1. [Enable internet traffic forwarding.](#enable-internet-traffic-forwarding)\n-1.
